awd_titl_txt: Reorganization of a Dopamine-Sensitive Locomotor Neural Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Almost all living organisms need to move for their survival, and that locomotion is often rhythmic and highly coordinated across an animal's legs, wings, fins, or other body parts.  How such coordination is orchestrated is not well understood, but the consequences of losing nerve cells that are vital for locomotion, for example, during a spinal cord injury, are strikingly clear.  This project examines how the nervous system can be retuned after a significant perturbation or injury to regain its former ability to generate rhythmic patterns of locomotion.  Such reorganization addresses an emerging and highly significant problem in the neurosciences -that of understanding the cellular mechanisms of homeostatic plasticity.  Essentially, this plasticity enables a system to go back to its set point or regain its original operational status after a perturbation.  Currently, very little is known about locomotor-related homeostatic mechanisms.  To understand such events, at the level of individual neurons, this project will use a combination of cellular, molecular and behavioral methods to study how a recovering nervous system achieves its transformation.   

The scientific team has chosen to study the medicinal leech as a model of locomotor control and homeostatic plasticity because of its experimental accessibility and well-studied locomotor circuits. Its central pattern generators (CPGs) for crawling behavior have been shown to be regulated by dopamine, a universal modulator of motor activity in most animals; each of these CPGs is located within each and every segmental ganglion comprising the nerve cord.  The compelling aspect of this project is discovering how the crawl CPGs become retuned or reconfigured so that all timing events are fully restored without the physical reconnection of cephalic inputs.  Three hypotheses will be tested: 1) proprioceptive inputs from the body wall substitute for brain-specific timing events; 2) the CPG in the ganglion immediately below the site of nerve cord injury takes the lead in initiating and directing the metachronal crawl waves in the caudal direction; 3) changes in gene expression patterns in the lead CPG provide for a lower crawl-activation threshold to DA and/or proprioceptive inputs.  Experimental methods will include electrophysiology, immunocytochemistry, confocal imaging, behavioral video-capture, computational neuroscience, and cutting-edge single-cell quantitative PCR. This project's outcomes have potential to impact disparate fields outside of the biological sciences, including physics, math, computer science and engineering.  The planned development of a leech transcriptome will also propel the medicinal leech model into the era of genomics. The project will support the training of female and minority participants, several leech-based laboratory teaching modules, and community outreach projects involving a leech Critter-Cam for middle school students.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of our project has been to understand how neural circuits are fundamentally organized, and then reorganized to permit the recovery of locomotion after injury. The form of locomotion that we have focused on is crawling in the medicinal leech, which consists of a highly coordinated sequence of metachronal waves that move in the anterior-to-posterior direction during each contraction and elongation phase of a crawl cycle.

Previously, we discovered that crawling is turned on by dopamine and is dependent (for initiation, maintenance and coordination) on a long-distance projecting interneuron (R3b-1) located in the brain. When we removed the entire brain, leeches were unable to crawl as predicted. By about 10 days after removing their brains, however, leeches showed a remarkable recovery of their crawling behavior, and by 20 days showed a graceful and coordinated crawling behavior indistinguishable from uninjured animals.

This unprecedented result afforded us the unique opportunity to explore various neural circuit designs for a common locomotor behavior in the very same animal. We determined that the leech has within its nervous system the potential for multiple solutions to generate crawling. To watch these animals crawl with no detectable deficit after removing the entirety of the brain's influence (with no reconnections) is unforgettable. One cannot help but wonder how this potential is maintained and then manifest. Indeed, these questions drove our research project.

Since beginning our studies, we have documented that regrowth or reestablishment of descending inputs is not responsible for the locomotor recovery observed. In contrast, we have determined and subsequently published that the reorganization of proprioceptive afferents is key to recovery; for example, preventing contact of the lead ganglion (ganglion directly below the site of nerve cord transection) with afferent input deprives the animal its ability to recover over time. During the latter part of our project, we characterized the specific afferent neurons that participate in locomotor recovery, which include a defined group of stretch receptors in the body wall of the animals studied. We also began to establish the time-course of morphological alterations that the stretch receptors reveal in the central nervous system as locomotor recovery progresses.

We also generated baseline data, to be used in future studies, so that we can understand the underlying gene regulatory changes that permit the homeostatic plasticity observed during recovery. To this end, we published the first comprehensive annotated transcriptome characterizing the leech CNS. We examined modulatory systems at the molecular level, in part, because potential recovery-related changes appear to involve alterations in the neurochemical systems that normally influence the known activation or suppression of crawling or swimming, including the up- or down-regulation of biogenic amines, their synthetic enzymes and/or their receptors. Our most recent physiological and molecular data support the idea that the anterior-most ganglion, below the site of nerve cord injury or brain removal, takes on some of the molecular characteristics common to that of the brain.

We have incorporated graduate students, postdocs and undergraduate students into our research project, and have disseminated our results in the form of peer-reviewed publications, lectures and presentations at meetings, in college-level courses and community events. The knowledge obtained from our studies will impact how mammalian locomotor control systems can be reorganized after injury, and will influence potential treatments of spinal cord injury and motor dysfunctions in humans. Soft-bodied robotics and the need for flexible locomotor algorithms will also benefit from our results and insights.
